Award.AwardTitle: MRSEC: Center for the Science and Engineering of Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Under renewed NSF support, The Center for the Science and Engineering of Materials (CSEM) at Caltech will carry forward its mission as a multifaceted materials research and education center. CSEM combines world-class materials research programs organized as interdisciplinary research groups and seed research projects, with educational programs serving underrepresented minority undergraduate, community college, and high school students across Southern California and also serving the general public via television-based mass media programming.

The Center will address both research and educational aspects of materials science in several areas: i) Macromolecular materials design to produce tailored responses to cellular adhesion and growth; ii) novel ferroelectric photonic materials that enable new freedoms in tuning the dispersion relations for photonic materials and devices and offer a new avenue for scientific progress in using light to understand complex materials behavior; and iii) advanced structural materials based on bulk metallic glass composites, with the potential to enable new amorphous structural materials with strength-to-weight ratio much higher than steel.

CSEM also supports emerging research areas via seed projects, which will focus on i) catalytic materials for chemical storage of hydrogen via methanol production and use in nonpolymer fuel cells based on "superprotonic" solid acids and ii) spintronic and optoelectronic properties of organic semiconductor/ferromagnetic heterostructures with applications in future electronic and quantum computing devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Science and Engineering of Materials (CSEM) at Caltech has created a multifaceted research and education enterprise combining world-class materials research programs with educational programs serving communities both within and external to Caltech. With support from the National Science Foundation, the center has addressed the most challenging and central problem in materials research – the atomic-level construction of materials displaying unique and targeted properties. Much of the research activity of the center has been focused on three Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs). IRG I – Active Nanophotonic Materials has taught us how to exploit the coupling between photonic, phononic and electronic responses of materials to manipulate light and sound waves with exquisite precision.  IRG II – Patterns, Gradients and Signals in Soft Biomaterials has developed new methods to prepare soft, bioactive materials whose physical features (e.g., compliance) and biochemical composition (e.g., the identity and density of adhesion ligands) may be varied independently, systematically and in spatially graded fashion to elicit predictable biological behavior.  IRG III – Advanced Structural Materials with Nanoscale Architecture – Glasses, Composites, and Cellular Foams has explored new structural forms of metallic glasses to design revolutionary structural engineering materials. The center has also supported vigorous seed programs that have helped to launch the careers of new assistant professors in pursuit of challenging materials problems.  In all of its activities, CSEM has remained committed to enhancing participation, through broad educational outreach programs and recruitment of talented students, post-doctoral scholars and faculty from underrepresented groups into the center research programs. Especially strong ties have been forged between Caltech and the California State University at Los Angeles.  The research and education mission has been further supported through the development of new instrumentation and lasting changes in the infrastructure for materials research on the Caltech campus.
